results.title: Wonders sacred and mysterious
results.creator_credit: Marianne Gammon and Reader's Digest Association
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great wonders of the world”.
Monuments of astonishing beauty and power such as Stonehenge, The Great Pyramids at Giza, Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, Borobudur in Java, St Peter’s Basilica in the Vatican City, and the Taj Mahal in Agra are all supreme examples of the human need to try and explain some of the mysteries of life, and the subject of this fascinating Reader’s Digest documentary.

results.title: Wonders of nature
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great wonders of the world”.
All nature’s miracles evoke a sense of wonder but in some places nature reveals her magnificence in very special ways. Witness the majesty of the following places: The Grand Canyon - Arizona, USA ; The Serengeti - Kenya/Tanzania, Africa ; The Sahara Desert - Niger, West Africa ; Iguazu Falls - Argentina/Brazil, South America ; The Amazon River - Brazil, South America ; Ayers Rock (Uluru) - Australia ; The Himalayas - Nepal, Asia.

results.title: Wonders of man's creations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great wonders of the world”.
When the urge to build conspires with a vision of beauty, man sometimes leaves behind an enduring mark. The following man-made marks are visited in this informative video: The Colosseum (Rome) ; Machu Pichu (Peru, South America) ; The Great Wall (China) ; The Kremlin (Russia) ; Versailles (France) ; The Statue of Liberty (New York city, USA) ; The Eiffel Tower (France) ; Mount Rushmore National Monument and Crazy Horse Monument (South Dakota, USA).

results.title: Robots for Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
A brief look at the work being carried out by the CSIRO in programming computers to carry out functions in the manufacturing industries. Also raises issues regarding the changing face of the worplace. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Clear, clean water
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Outlines a new process for water purification called Sirofloc, developed by the CSIRO, and explains it in the context of Australia’s limited water resources. Looks at the first commercial plant in Perth.

results.title: Predation of cossid moth larvae by yellow-tailed black cockatoos
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Shows how the yellow-tailed black cockatoo extracts cossid moth larvae from the trunks of eucalypts and covers other aspects of the behaviour of the bird and its prey, emphasizing the role of evolutionary adaptation. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Operation flower pot
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
The CSIRO is currently involved in the unravelling of the intricacies of the complex ecosystems of the South Australian forest. The film shows an experiment being conducted to determine and measure how plants use water in the forest. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Lucerne: a stronger shade of green
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Lucerne is one of the richest feed crops grown for livestock and an important source of nitrogen for the soil. In 1977 varieties of aphids began attacking this vital crop. This film shows programs begun by the CSIRO to counter the aphid attacks.
